questions.text: Right hepatic duct drains all, except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Segment III is drained by left hepatic duct. Option C and D that Is segment V and VI are drained by right hepatic duct. Option A that is segement I is unique in its nature as it is drained by both right and left hepatic duct.

questions.text: Surgeon excises a portion of liver to the left of the attachment of the falciform ligament. The segments that have been resected are (LQ)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

The plane passing through the falciform ligament passes through the left lobe of liver and It divides the left lobe into a medial segment (segment IV) and lateral segment (segment II and III). So if the surgeon resects the segments to the left of falciform ligament he has basically resected segment II and III of liver.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of pyogenic liver abscess?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Most common cause of pyogenic liver abscess is ascending infection from biliary tract due to a distal obstruction. Most common cause of a distal obstruction is stones, but it can also occur because of cholangiocarcinoma. Option A is wrong as trauma can be a cause of a pyogenic liver abscess but it is not the most common cause Colonic diverticulosis and ruptured appendicitis are the other causes of pyogenic liver abscess but they are not the most common cause.

questions.text: False statement about hydatid disease is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

• PAIR (Percutaneous aspiration, injection of sclerosing agent and reapiration)- performed using either ultrasound or CT guidance, involves aspiration of the contents via a special cannula, followed by injection of a scolicidal agent for at least 15 minutes, and then reaspiration. This is repeated until the return is clear. Perioperative treatment with a benzimidazole is mandatory.

• The PAIR technique can be performed on liver, bone, and kidney cysts but should not be performed on lung and brain cysts.

• Contraindications: Early pregnancy, lung cysts, inaccessible cysts, superficially located cysts (risk of spillage), type II honeycomb cysts, type IV cysts, and cysts communicating with the biliary tree (risk of sclerosing cholangitis from the scolecoidal agent) are contraindications for the PAIR technique.

questions.text: A 40 year old gentleman presented to surgical emergency with history of high grade fever along with severe pain right upper abdomen of 2 days duration and diarrhoea. On examination the patient is febrile and has a tender hepatomegaly. Ultrasound examination revealed a 6cm X 4 cm solitary abscess in the right lobe of liver along with small right pleural effusion. CECT should double ring sign. What should be the most appropriate management strategy in the patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

 Liver abscess of > 5 cm needs to be aspirated or drained along with metronidazole. A small pleural effusion in patients of liver abscess is most likely to be reactive and if not causing any respiratory symptoms does not need a chest tube insertion

questions.text: Exposure of PVC is associated with which type of liver cancer?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Angiosarcoma is described as a high-grade, malignant neoplasm of endothelial cells of blood or lymphatic vessels. Primary hepatic angiosarcoma is most common primary malignant mesenchymal tumor of the liver in adults. Around 75% of tumors have no known etiology, but the most common known etiologic factors are exposure to vinyl chloride monomer and other industrial materials, iatrogenic exposure to colloidal thorium dioxide (Thorotrast), androgenic steroid use, chronic arsenic ingestion, and exposure to radium.

Neurotensin is the main tumour marker and is also used as a marker for therapeutic response.

questions.text: A 50 year old female, known diabetic with controlled blood sugar, presented with right upper abdominal pain and fever. O/E her BP is 105/70 and PR is 102/ min. Murphey’s sign is positive. CT picture is given below. What is the diagnosis and best treatment for her?

Emphysematous cholecystitis caused by clostridia should be treated by immediate cholecystectomy.

questions.text:
A 60 year old lady, a known case of gall stone was admitted with small bowel obstruction. She was considered a high risk case due to many medical co-morbidities. CECT showed Rigler’s triad. What should be ideal treatment for her?

.

Chose the single best response:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

• Gall stones ileus is when small bowel obstruction is caused by impacted gall stone at terminal ileum.  

• The stone enter bowel through fistula between gall bladder and duodenum, not through CBD so CBD remains normal. 

• CECT is IOC. CT or X ray will reveal Riggler’s triad 

• Riggler’s triad is characterized by 

1. Multiple air fluid levels, 

2. Radio-opaque shadow in ileum and 

3. Air in biliary tree. 

• Gall stone Ileum is treated by laparotomy and removal of impacted stone from ileum. Fistula closure and cholecystectomy is not done routinely at the time of emergency procedure and is only reserved for medically fit patients. It is done later on as a second stage operation.

Correct Answer (C)

WES is a feature of chronic cholecystitis which is best managed by planned laparoscopic cholecystectomy.

questions.text: Best treatment for a patient who presents with Reynolds pentad is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Patient is suffering from cholangitis and choledocholithiasis and should be managed by ERCP followed by laparoscopic cholecystectomy.
IV antibiotics and aggressive hydration are the initial treatment in patients with acute cholangitis. Biliary decompression may be performed endoscopically or by a percutaneous transhepatic route based on the level of the obstruction. 

Patients with acute cholangitis should be treated with systemic antibiotics and other supportive measures this usually controls the attack within 24–48 hours. If the patient's condition worsens or if marked improvement is not observed within 2–4 days, endoscopic sphincterotomy or surgery and common bile duct exploration should be performed.

choices.text: Cholecystectomy with resection of the extrahepatic biliary tract and Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with abdominal pain and jaundice. Subsequent “MRCP” reveals a cystic anomaly of her biliary system illustrated in the film shown here. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

This is type I choledochal cyst which is the commonest type (>85%)

Five major types are (Todani):

• Type I cysts are the most common and represent 80-90% of choledochal cysts. They consist of saccular or fusiform dilatations of the common bile duct, which involve either a segment of the duct or the entire duct. 

• Type II choledochal cysts appear as an isolated diverticulum protruding from the wall of the common bile duct. 

• Type III choledochal cysts arise from the intraduodenal portion of the common bile duct (choledochocele).

questions.text: 2.5 years Post cholecystectomy patients come with CBD stone? What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

A "retained CBD stone" refers to a gallstone that was missed during a procedure to remove stones from the common bile duct (CBD), essentially a stone that was left behind, while a "recurrent CBD stone" is a new stone that forms in the CBD after an initial procedure to remove stones, meaning it developed sometime after the initial treatment.
Retained is found within 2 years and recurrent is found after 2 years.

Recurrent stone is primary stone and usually made up of brown pigment stone.

choices.text: Laparoscopic cholecystectomy with Port site excision

questions.text: What is best treatment for GB cancer involving muscle of GB is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Treatment

• Simple cholecystectomy for Tis and T1a lesions 

• Extended (radical cholecystectomy) for T1b lesions and T2 tumors- Cholecystectomy with 1 cm adjoining tissue of liver or “en bloc” resection of the liver bed (Couinaud segments 4B and 5).

• T3 tumors perforate the serosa and/or directly invade adjacent organs so they are treated by radical resection of the involved organ.

• T4 tumors are usually not amenable to surgical resection

• lymphadenectomy is advocated in GBC as a staging procedure not for survival.

• If the cystic duct margin is positive, then bile duct excision and Roux en y reconstruction should be done.

• The benefit of excision of Port Site Resection is not supported by data.

• The role of adjuvant radiotherapy or chemoradiotherapy has been poor. 

• Gemcitabine and cisplatin or 5 FU is used a adjuvant therapy.

questions.text: On abdominal USG gall bladder shows diffuse wall thickening and comet tail artefact. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

• Gallbladder adenomyomatosis is excessive epithelial proliferation associated with hyperplasia of the muscularis propria, resulting in gallbladder wall thickening.

• The excessive epithelial proliferation leads to epithelial infolding within the underlying muscular layer the so-called Rokitansky–Aschoff sinuses (RAS)

• The Bile in RAS with time gets inspissated forming cholesterine crystal precipitation and intramural dystrophic calcification.

• The serosa is never involved.

GB cancer

• F: M = 3:1

• Type of stone does not correlate with risk only duration correlates

• Adenocarcinoma- 85%

• Fundus- 60%

• Acalculus ca more common in females

• Papillary sub type grows intraluminally and spreads intraductally- less aggressive and better prognosis

• Most common presentation- Cholecystitis

• IOC- CECT

• Tumor marker- Ca 19-9

• Port site excision does not improve survival

questions.text: Match the following regarding cystic lesions of pancreas?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Cystic Lesions of the Pancreas

Most (70% to 80%) cystic lesions of the pancreas are nonneoplastic (either pseudocysts complicating acute or chronic pancreatitis, or, rarely, true cysts). However, 15% of cystic lesions are neoplastic.

Table shows a simple classification scheme for cystic neoplasms of the pancreas. The 4 types most frequently encountered are mucinous cystic neoplasm (including mucinous cystadenocarcinoma and mucinous cystadenoma), serous cystadenoma, papillary cystic neoplasm, and intraductal papillary mucinous tumor.

choices.text: It may be found anywhere from mediastinum to scrotum.
Most common site is lesser sac
Any cyst located below transverse mesocolon is best treated by cystojejunostomy
Pseudocyst develops only after 4 weeks due to epithelization of the wall.

questions.text: False statement about pseudopancreatic cyst is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)  

Pseudocyst in not lined by epithelium. It is only lined by granulation tissue. 

Pseudocyst of pancreas is fibrosed walling off of peripancreatic fluid collection. It takes place only after 4 weeks. It is lined by Granulataion tissue (No epithelial lining)

About >85% are present in lesser sac but it may be found anywhere in retroperitoneum. It may extent into mediastinum or into scrotum. 

Cystogastrostomy (Jurasz) procedure is preferred treatment for psudopancreatic cyst when it is situated in lesser sac.. It is done after 6 weeks and when size is more than 5 cm.

For low lying pseudocyst (extending below transeverse mesocolon, cystojejunostomy is a preferred procedure).

80% patients of acute pancreatitis respond to conservative treatment.

A pancreatic tumour showing blush on angiography and presenting with hypoglycaemia is insulinoma. A < 2cm size Insulinoma is considered benign and is treated by Enucleation.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with severe epigastric pain and vomiting. Abdominal film shows absent psoas shadow and ‘sentinel loop’ of proximal jejunum. What do you expect in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

In acute pancreatitis absence of the psoas shadow is due to a build-up of retroperitoneal fluid. The sentinel loop refers to a segment of gas-filled proximal jejunum. However, it is important to remember that an abdominal plain film can be completely normal in a patient presenting with acute pancreatitis. CT scan is the investigation of choice. 
CT scan is the most reliable imaging modality in the diagnosis of acute pancreatitis. The criteria for the diagnosis are divided by Balthazar and colleagues into 5 grades
Grade A: Normal pancreas

Grade B: Focal or diffuse gland enlargement

Grade C: Intrinsic gland abnormality seen by haziness on the scan

Grade D: Single ill-defined collection or phlegmon

Grade E: Two or more ill-defined collections or the presence of gas in or nearby, the pancreas
